name: Mysore
fun_fact: Fun fact: Mysore Pak was invented by accident in the royal kitchens of the Mysore Palace in the early 1900sâ€”when the chef Kakasura Madappa created a concoction of ghee, sugar, and chickpea flour, the king loved it so much he named it 'Mysore Pak' (Mysore sweet), and his descendants still make it using the original recipe.

hero_dishes.name: Mysore Masala Dosa at Vinayaka Mylari Hotel
hero_dishes.description: Thick, soft, fluffy dosa with crispy edges, smeared with spicy red garlic chutney and filled with potato masalaâ€”not the thin crispy version, but Mysore's unique style
hero_dishes.origin_story: Vinayaka Mylari Hotel is 80 years old and serves only idli, dosa, and masala dosa. Their Mysore benne (butter) masala dosa is smaller and thicker than elsewhere, soft inside and crisp outside. Locals line up for this specific dosa
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Vinayaka Mylari Hotel (Nazarbad Main Roadâ€”two original locations near each other), Gayathri Tiffin Room, or Hotel Nalpak

hero_dishes.name: Mysore Pak at Guru Sweet Mart
hero_dishes.description: Crumbly, melt-in-your-mouth sweet made from chickpea flour, ghee, and sugarâ€”rich, buttery, and impossibly decadent
hero_dishes.origin_story: Over 100 years ago, chef Kakasura Madappa created Mysore Pak in the royal kitchens. His descendants still operate Guru Sweet Mart on Sayyaji Road, using the exact same recipe. This is the ONLY authentic Mysore Pakâ€”accept no substitutes
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Guru Sweet Mart (Sayyaji Roadâ€”owned by Kakasura Madappa's descendants, original recipe since 1900s)

hero_dishes.name: Mutton Pulao at Hotel Hanumanthu Original 1930
hero_dishes.description: Fragrant rice cooked with tender mutton, spices, and herbsâ€”the favorite breakfast for Mysore locals
hero_dishes.origin_story: Hotel Hanumanthu serves mutton pulao for breakfast, which sounds insane until you try it. This 1930s institution is where hardcore meat-lovers start their day. It's become a Mysore tradition
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Hotel Hanumanthu Original 1930 (near Ballal Circleâ€”meat for breakfast since 1930)

hero_dishes.name: Bisi Bele Bath
hero_dishes.description: Spicy rice and lentil dish cooked with vegetables, tamarind, and a special spice blendâ€”Karnataka's comfort food
hero_dishes.origin_story: A tiny restaurant near Ballal Circle (one of Mysore's oldest hotels) serves the best bisi bele bath. This is Karnataka's answer to khichdiâ€”one-pot comfort food with heat, tang, and richness
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Old hotel near Ballal Circle, or any traditional South Indian restaurant in Mysore

signature_drinks.name: South Indian Filter Coffee
signature_drinks.description: Strong, frothy coffee made with dark-roasted beans, mixed with hot milk and sugarâ€”served in a steel tumbler and davara (saucer)
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Coffee in Mysore is an art form. It's poured back and forth between tumbler and saucer to cool it and create froth. Locals drink it throughout the day at tiny coffee stalls

signature_drinks.name: Buttermilk (Majjige)
signature_drinks.description: Spiced, salted yogurt drink tempered with curry leaves and mustard seedsâ€”cooling and digestive
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served cold with meals, especially after spicy dishes. The salt and spices aid digestion and cool you down in Mysore's heat

food_culture_notes: Authentic Mysore dosa is NOT thin and crispyâ€”it's thick, soft, and fluffy with crisp edges
Guru Sweet Mart's Mysore Pak is the only real thingâ€”the recipe hasn't changed in over 100 years
Mutton pulao for breakfast might shock tourists, but locals swear by it at Hotel Hanumanthu
Mysore's food culture is deeply South Indian with its own unique twists (thicker dosas, royal sweets)

unique_modern: Guru Sweet Mart preserving 100+-year-old royal recipe
Vinayaka Mylari's 80-year-old dosa technique (thick not thin)
Hotel Hanumanthu's breakfast mutton pulao since 1930
Mysore as UNESCO City of Yoga (but food is equally important)
